instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00281: What is 820-00281? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.SMC_LID_RIGHT: What is SMC_LID_RIGHT? SMC_LID_RIGHT is a signal that tells the system if the lid is closed from the right LID sensor. If it is low, the system thinks the lid is closed – if it is 3.3v, the system thinks the machine is open. SMC_LID_RIGHT needs to be high for the machine to stay awake and have a backlight. .
definitions.SMC_LID_LEFT: What is SMC_LID_LEFT? SMC_LID_LEFT is a signal that tells the system if the lid is closed from the left LID sensor. If it is low, the system thinks the lid is closed – if it is 3.3v, the system thinks the machine is open. SMC_LID_LEFT needs to be high for the machine to stay awake and have a backlight. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0SW_LCD: What is PP3V3_S0SW_LCD? PP3V3_S0SW_LCD is a 3.3v power rail necessary to power the image circuitry on the screen. This is necessary to get a picture on the screen. .
definitions.EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN: What is EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN? EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN is necessary to enable the power rail that powers the LCD screen image circuitry. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.A1707: What is A1707? A1707 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Late 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3072, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00281, 820-00928..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Image
threads.message:
Hey guys. I got a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> in that was liquid damaged and has a lot of issues. It originally had only 5v on the charger and I replaced UB300/400 and also had to replace the resistors around UB090 and run a wire from CB090 to RB090 to restore 20v. Still did not boot due to a short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>. Found that PPBUS was shorted to ground through CA325. This whole area looked bad so I replaced CA325 and QA300. The board then turned on but had high fan spin on the left fan only. This was because <TRANSISTOR>Q6000</TRANSISTOR> was missing from the board. Replaced that and also has to replace one of the hall sensors because it was damaged. The board boots now and seems to run normally except for a few issues. The main issue is that the internal display only has backlight and no image. I tested with a known good full assembly and had the same issue. External display works fine. It also take a long time to boot into the OS (about 3 minutes). The keyboard backlight also does not come on when you first boot the computer, but does come on if I close the lid and re-open it. Seems like this would be a issue with <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> but the voltages seem normal. I replaced <CHIP>U9850</CHIP> to try and fix the image issues but that did not help. Still have just backlight on the LCD. Here are some of the voltages I got for the screen.


<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0SW_LCD</SIGNAL> - 5.1
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0SW_LCD</SIGNAL> - 3.3
<SIGNAL>EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> - 3.3
<SIGNAL>PANEL_FET_EN_DLY</SIGNAL> - 3.4
<SIGNAL>DFR_DISP_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> - 3.4
<SIGNAL>BUF_EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> - 3.4
<SIGNAL>BUF_SMC_REST_L</SIGNAL> - 3.4
<SIGNAL>DFR_DISP_SMC_RST_L</SIGNAL> - 3.4
<SIGNAL>DP_INT_HPD</SIGNAL> - 3.3
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> - 3.4
<SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> - 3.4
<SIGNAL>SMC_LID_RIGHT</SIGNAL> - 3.4
<SIGNAL>SMC_LID_LEFT</SIGNAL> - 3.4

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Image
threads.message:
If you get backlight, all power rails for LCD connector should be good.
You must have a problem with data lines.
Compare diode mode to ground on all them.

Do you get black, or white screen?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Image
threads.message: I checked all the <SIGNAL>EDP_INT_ML</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>EDP_AUXCH</SIGNAL> lines and compared their diode mode values to another good board and they are very similar. <SIGNAL>EDP_INT_ML</SIGNAL> lines are about .314 (.323 on a good board), and <SIGNAL>EDP_AUXCH</SIGNAL> is about .401 (good board .406). I only get backlight and a black screen.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Image
threads.message:
Did you pick <CHIP>U9850</CHIP> from liquid damaged board?
Try to reflow it, in case of bad solders.
Also check for knocked off components around it.
Inspect J8500 traces and contacts.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Image
threads.message: I used a new <CHIP>U9850</CHIP> that was bought online. I tried to reflow it with no change. I also tried replacing it again with one from a donor board and still have the same symptoms. I did not find any knocked off components near that chip. J8500 looks fine and all the traces and contacts appear normal.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Image
threads.message:
Are you sure tested LCD assembly is compatible with this model?
Check diode mode at all data input lines of <CHIP>U9850</CHIP>.
Also post voltage for <SIGNAL>LCD_MUX_EN</SIGNAL>/SEL; with LCD connected, of course.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Image
threads.message: I just got in another <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> with a working screen and tested this board with that screen and is it actually getting image now. I think I previously did have an issue with <CHIP>U9850</CHIP> that was fixed but the display I was testing with seems to also be broken so it was screwing me up. Image works fine on this board now but I am still having an issue with the board booting slowly and it also sometimes will boot to the critical software update screen for the touch bar. Its weird because I will only get to that screen like 10% of the time I try and boot. The rest of the time it boots slowly but get to the OS with a working touch bar. Do you know what would cause this issue?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Image
threads.message: Try clean ME BIOS first...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Image
threads.message: I tried a clean me bios I found online but now it does not boot. It tries to boot and then restarts and shows the kernel panic error screen. Do you have a clean me bios for this model?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Image
threads.message:
Not really sure if good
[url]https://drive.google.com/open?id=16adJEM165cARymUCKK6_NZ2w3GbjtOFv[/url]
Try it and comment...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Image
threads.message: Thanks! This does seem to be good because the board now boots again but its still very slow to get to the login screen. Takes about 3-4 minutes from the time I hit the power button until I am able to login. The first time I booted with this ME, it booted to the critical software update screen but I did not have the wifi connected. I shut it down and re connected the wifi antenna cables and then turned it on again and it booted to the login screen this time after about 4 minutes, with a working touch bar. It takes just as long to boot into a test OS from a USB drive also.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Image
threads.message:
Run HWMonitor and see if reports any strange sensor value.
Fans spin normal?
Do you have Medusa programmer?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Image
threads.message: HWMonitor reports all normal temperatures and the fans spin normally at around 2000 rpm. I do not have a Medusa programmer. I used a CH341A programmer and Flashrom to flash the chip. Diagnostic only reports that the battery is not detected since this one has a bad battery in it right now and I have it disconnected while I wait for a new battery.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Image
threads.message: If I try and boot without the wifi cables connected, it will always boot to the critical software update screen, but if I have the wifi cables connected, it will boot slowly to the login screen. I plugged in the wifi cables once it got to the update screen and then downloaded the update without issue and the board booted. The update takes about 3 minutes to install so what it seems like to me is it is not saving the touchbar update when I reboot and has to re download it each time I start the computer. Is the touchbar driver/update saved on the internal SSD?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Image
threads.message:
The touchbar driver should be saved on the SSD.
Recover the data and do fresh install.

PRAM reset tried 2-3 times?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Image
threads.message: Yes I have tried a PRAM reset and also did a fresh install multiple times and always the same issue. It does not seem to be software related. When the computer gets to the login screen, it works completely normally.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Image
threads.message: Did you write the BIOS file as is, or changed serial number first?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Image
threads.message: I changed the serial number of the file you gave me first and then wrote it to the chip.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Image
threads.message:
If you change serial number, Fsys checksum must be fixed.
Try the file as is, to discard a BIOS issue.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Image
threads.message: Yea I am pretty sure I fixed the checksum properly when I changed the serial number, but just to make sure, I took your suggestion and flashed the chip with the clean ME you provided, as-is but still have the same issue. I don't think this is a BIOS issue but have no idea what could be causing this.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Image
threads.message: If you have Medusa programmer, then clean ME into original BIOS.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Image
threads.message: I do not have a medusa programmer. I downloaded the correct Clean ME version for my original BIOS and copied it into the original BIOS but still have the same issue. Board still boots slow but then works fine once it does boot. Still trying to find something else wrong on this board but am not having any luck.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Image
threads.message:
"I downloaded the correct Clean ME version for my original BIOS and copied it into the original BIOS"
I'm not sure if you understood how to clean ME region; surely not copy/paste...

Upload somewhere your original BIOS.
I hope you made a backup first.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Image
threads.message:
No I did not just copy and paste it. I followed this guide on win-raid.com on how to clean the ME region using the Intel Flash image tool. [URL="https://www.win-raid.com/t1658f39-Guide-Clean-Dumped-Intel-Engine-CS-ME-CS-TXE-Regions-with-Data-Initialization.html"]https://www.win-raid.com/t1658f39-Gu...alization.html[/URL]

Here are both my original and cleaned BIOS files. Idk if you can tell if its cleaned correctly or not. 

Original: [URL]https://drive.google.com/open?id=1MrCADRie4QPHIicBDTZWFevNasGenf8F[/URL]

Clean: [URL]https://drive.google.com/open?id=1WN3Vprn96rr5Tjm_C-WUo5neepsSxhgk[/URL]
